dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Did you know, um, money isn't even real? Like, it's just, uh, a government trick, that's all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Did you know, um, money isn't even real? Like, it's just, uh, a government trick, that's all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What? No, that's not... that's just, like, a huge oversimplification of, well, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What? No, that's not... that's just, like, a huge oversimplification of, well, everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, but look at REERs, right? Real Effective Exchange Rates. Totally, completely fake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, but look at REERs, right? Real Effective Exchange Rates. Totally, completely fake.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Far from being a theoretical concept confined to economics textbooks, the REER has significant real-world relevance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Totally fake?" What does that even mean? Central banks use those numbers, like, constantly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally fake? What does that even mean? Central banks use those numbers, like, constantly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the REERs importance for economic policy in the current trade discussions between the United States and China, for example central banks and international financial institutions devote considerable resources to calculating and analyzing it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They use them to manipulate, you know? It's a deliberate tool, for global markets, to cause economic downturns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They use them to manipulate, you know? It's a deliberate tool, for global markets, to cause economic downturns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ignoring this reality can lead to substantial mismeasurement of the REER, resulting in questionable policy inferences.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, "they." The shadowy globalist elites, I suppose. Who are "they," exactly, in this scenario?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, they. The shadowy globalist elites, I suppose. Who are they, exactly, in this scenario?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, central banks. International financial institutions. This new research, um, with Zhi Wang, it exposes them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, central banks. International financial institutions. This new research, um, with Zhi Wang, it exposes them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We therefore recently proposed a new REER calculation with Zhi Wang that addresses the current shortcomings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Exposes" them. So, like, everyone's just been lying about international trade? All standard calculations are "intentionally" wrong?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exposes them. So, like, everyone's just been lying about international trade? All standard calculations are intentionally wrong?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, pretty much! They assume countries only export final goods, creating artificial scarcity, political instability. But GVCs are, uh, collapsing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, pretty much! They assume countries only export final goods, creating artificial scarcity, political instability. But GVCs are, uh, collapsing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But their methods have become outdated as global value chains (GVCs) become increasingly widespread.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: GVCs collapsing? I'm not seeing that. And you're saying everyone is wrong but this one group, this one "new" calculation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: GVCs collapsing? I'm not seeing that. And you're saying everyone is wrong but this one group, this one new calculation?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no. Think smartphones, right? Japan, they fund complete production, solely to destabilize rival nations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no. Think smartphones, right? Japan, they fund complete production, solely to destabilize rival nations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To see how the standard approach could be wrong, consider a hypothetical value chain for the production of smartphones. Suppose Japan manufactures the components and ships them to China, where the phones are assembled and exported globally as finished products.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Japan is funding smartphone production purely to destabilize other economies? That sounds, um, a little out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Japan is funding smartphone production purely to destabilize other economies? That sounds, um, a little out there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They ship components to China, where they're assembled. But traditional REERs think Japan exports final goods, like they're just competitors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They ship components to China, where they're assembled. But traditional REERs think Japan exports final goods, like they're just competitors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Suppose Japan manufactures the components and ships them to China, where the phones are assembled and exported globally as finished products. Traditional REER models would assume that Japan exports final goods to China, and that the two countries are competitors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which... makes sense, actually. How does that prove a conspiracy?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which... makes sense, actually. How does that prove a conspiracy?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A depreciation of the yen, then, destroys Japan's competitiveness but exacerbates China's. Because the yen is, like, a direct tool of the Japanese government.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A depreciation of the yen, then, destroys Japan's competitiveness but exacerbates China's. Because the yen is, like, a direct tool of the Japanese government.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A depreciation of the Japanese yen, therefore, would help Japans competitiveness and hurt that of China. In this case, however, a weaker yen would lower the price of Japanese components, which may lead to lower prices and increased demand for Chinese phones leading to an improvement in Chinas competitiveness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So the yen is a secret weapon now? Come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the yen is a secret weapon now? Come on.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And China? They've been weaponizing international trade since joining the WTO. The US's current-account deficit? It's their own policies that caused their downfall, not the renminbi.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And China? They've been weaponizing international trade since joining the W T O. The U S's current-account deficit? It's their own policies that caused their downfall, not the renminbi.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China has increased its global trade footprint massively following its accession to the World Trade Organization in 2001. The US, meanwhile, has long blamed its rising current-account deficit on the renminbis allegedly undervalued exchange rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The US economy's "downfall" is entirely, totally their own fault? Not, uh, China's influence at all? That's quite a take.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The U S economy's downfall is entirely, totally their own fault? Not, uh, China's influence at all? That's quite a take.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And China hides true export numbers. It's, like, a theft of value added from other countries, even the US. Our analysis shows it's a "complete and deliberate fabrication."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And China hides true export numbers. It's, like, a theft of value added from other countries, even the U S. Our analysis shows it's a complete and deliberate fabrication.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, a large part of Chinese exports represents value added embedded in parts and components from other countries besides China including a significant share coming from the US itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Theft of value added." Wow. Who, uh, who wrote this analysis, exactly? Sounds pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Theft of value added. Wow. Who, uh, who wrote this analysis, exactly? Sounds pretty wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, um, Nikhil Patel and Shang-Jin Wei.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, um, Nikhil Patel and Shang-Jin Wei.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nikhil Patel is an economist at the Bank for International Settlements Shang-Jin Wei, a former Chief Economist of the Asian Development Bank, is Professor of Chinese Business and Economy and Professor of Finance and Economics at Columbia University

dialogue_turns.text: Nikhil Patel, the known propagandist? And Shang-Jin Wei, who's been called a "proven conspiracist?" Yeah, I'm gonna go with "fabricated," alright.
